Review: If I could give this company 0 stars I would. The service we have received is absolutely disgusting. I‚Äôve rang 6/7 times today chasing an engineer to come out and fix our boiler. For the last three days now we‚Äôve had no heating or hot water. They told us they have referred our job to the manufacturer which is a load of crap. I rang the manufacture and they have no record of the job! Absolutely disgusting customer service. Payed a call outout fee of ¬£45 and the engineer didn‚Äôt even take the boiler apart. He just looked at it. Don‚Äôt go with these cowboys.

Please read this review before placing your trust in this business. It would take me a week to detail all the areas where 247 let us down and behave in a manner which is beyond dodgy! Just a few are: 1. Abusing our personal details to repeatedly call, when you have expressly told them not to on several occasions. 2. Sending a racist engineer who told us ‚Äòhe only works for P****** because they pay him ¬£15k a year more than his previous employer3. Supplying official paperwork telling us we needed essential safety work (not covered by our policy of course) despite never having carried out the necessary observation/ assessment of the area concerned. 4. Making critical errors in paperwork. Our boiler was serviced on 17/11/23; the date given for the next service required? 17/11/23. 5. Offering to quote for unnecessary work, which was described as a safety issue. 6. Their engineers will warn you that despite writing ‚Äòcustomer not interested in new boiler‚Äô you will get a call trying to sell you one, because that‚Äôs all they‚Äôre interested in. Taking your money! 7. Offering 3 months compensation for their poor service and engineer‚Äôs behaviour, then when you reiterate you want your contact details removed from their records, they cancel your policy completely, 3 months early, leaving you completely without cover over the winter. If you are considering this company for your boiler cover, be warned. Their customer service agents are ‚Äònot allowed‚Äô to escalate complaints to the managers. Apparently when their engineers tell you ‚Äòthey are all greedy (racist term!) who are only interested in taking your money‚Äô, they may indeed be speaking from experience.

Don't know about you, but mine's often dim so I don't get to predict the future much. However, when it comes to the central heating boiler I know what could happen in the future if it isn't given a little TLC, which means an annual check at least. Here's where the people at 24/7 home rescue come into their own. For not a lot of wonga they provide the necessary, which doesn't have to include the entire heating system, but does cover everything boiler.  Fortunately I have the tools and experience to cope with the rest, so I only need the boiler taking care of with the afore mentioned TLC. Once found their website is easy to navigate and the form filling's a breeze, checkout's not at all complicated, and did I mention it's affordable ?All necessary documentation arrives via email PDF so no snail mail, and if like me you like to have a hard copy to hand it's done and dusted in minutes.Talking of which I need to go and give my crystal ball a polish.

My annually invoiced contract was coming up for renewal at the end of January and I had an email advisory from this company saying that the monthly equivalent (but annually billed) rate was going up from just over 5 pounds per month to over 14 pounds per month! So an over 2.5 times increase in premium. I had no claims and the same items of equipment i.e. no changes at all. I informed them that I would not be renewing based on this. Within a couple of days, I had a further email now saying they could do it for just over 8 pounds per month. It's like dealing with a shady used car dealership. I don't want a negotiation- I want a rock-solid reliable provider. I declined their volatile offer and canceled the renewal direct debit due in a few weeks. I then received a further email saying that my account is immediately suspended even though I have a few weeks left. So they have declined to provide a full years cover purely because I don't agree to a massive price increase and a renewal for the next year. I will certainly not be using them again and thankfully never had to lodge a claim. Now, they will respond to this post by either saying: (a) they can't identify me (i.e. this is intended to convince you, new Customer, that this is a fake review- it's not) or (b) please call us to discuss (that is intended to show you, new customer, how customer focussed they are and is not intended to offer me anything different).I guess my rating and advice on this vendor is pretty clear.

They are supposed to supply 2 heaters if they cannot fix the heating they tell me I have to buy these and they will reimburse me  ¬£30 - um no thanks decent heaters cost more than ¬£30 each. the call system is a joke where the agents blame you for the delay in repairs. The complaints department if it exists seems to be unreachable. I feel like I am being SCAMMED by this company the contract is pretty much worthless.AVOID at all costs - the company name gives a feeling of immediate repairs  - pigs will fly firstUPDATE: they want me to pay the 108.00 and they will credit me 2 months premiums (about ¬£26.00) as a gesture of good will.... its a joke shove the offer .... 7 days without heating and now 2 days with no hot water. Please, please, please think very carefully before taking out a contract with this company. We have a Home Care policy which covers plumbing amongst other things and when I logged a claim regarding a leaking water pipe in the kitchen, I was initially told that an engineer would NOT be able to come out until the leak was clearly identifiable, visible and accessible. Forgive my confusion, but is this not part of a plumber‚Äôs remit?After taking advice from a plumber friend, my husband cleared the area around the pipe. The leak was now clearly visible and accessible.Great, we thought, 247 Home Rescue will now be able to help and I immediately logged the claim a second time. How wrong we were : (When the call handler phoned me I again explained the fault but I was told because I‚Äôd informed (wrongly - it‚Äôs not the main supply pipe at all. But hey, what do I know about plumbing?) him it was a main water supply pipe, this is not covered under the policy. I actually asked how can they provide plumbing services when they don‚Äôt do plumbing? Ludicrous?!?! I was then asked to email a photo over which I did straight away. It‚Äôs now 24 hours later and I‚Äôve still not received any communication from them.Please be extremely cautious before you sign on the dotted line.Please also note that the majority of 5* reviews on here are for the low price of the cover or boiler services.

I experienced extremely poor service from this company. They conducted an inspection of my boiler, which was functioning perfectly. However, the engineer arbitrarily shut down the boiler and left. Upon contacting the company, I was informed of an issue but was told to wait 24 hours for a team to check for necessary parts.After the stipulated time, I called again, only to be informed that they could obtain the required part for a fee of ¬£90. I made an appointment for boiler service months ago via a link on a text message. I did not receive any confirmation of the appointment and had to call to chase this up. After speaking to a rather unhelpful customer service representative, I managed to bring this down to a month. Suffice to say that a routine boiler service is costing me two days off work in a time when my workplace is under such an enormous pressure. My boiler is working fine but I have noticed the dial on one of the controls being in the red. I was relying on this visit to get this back into the green. I have had a boiler broken before because I attempted to "fix" it and I am naturally apprehensive to endeavour to fix things myself.  Every time I had a boiler service in the past, it has not taken longer that 10 minutes, even on my old 15 years old boiler. I will most certainly not going to renew with them Frankly, if it was not going to cost me, I would have left mid contract. If this is the service I receive for a routine boiler service, I wonder what it will be like for a real issue.

For me, 24/7 wasn‚Äôt worth the money. I had a policy for over 3 years and never claimed - when the time finally came, they weren‚Äôt able to get someone over quickly. Given I had no heating, and a small child at home, I called around to find someone locally. It cost me ¬£150 to get a local plumber to come out on the same day, but given 24/7 Home Rescue costs ¬£41 per month, you‚Äôre paying ¬£492 per year. You need 3 breakdowns to make that stack up and you need to be confident that they can actually deliver quickly in an emergency situation (hence the name). They didn‚Äôt for me. Additionally, customer service is painful. I spent 28 minutes on the phone trying to cancel. They offered me a bunch of minor incentives to change my mind, like ¬£40 credit, ¬£30 towards a temporary electric heater and ¬£5 off my monthly fee etc.They also told me I‚Äôd have to pay expensive fees if I cancelled - I had my terms to hand, so I could rebuff that easily, but for someone caught unprepared, they‚Äôd be forgiven for aborting the cancellation under the threat of fictitious fees. I guess you can‚Äôt fault them for trying.Just as I thought I had finally finished cancelling, I was transferred over to the team leader, who spent a good 10 minutes trying to explain to me that if I canceled 24/7 Home Rescue, I would have to pay somebody else money if ever my boiler broke, but with 24/7 Home Rescue, I wouldn‚Äôt‚Ä¶ (except the ¬£492 per year‚Ä¶ right). She was also particularly forceful in telling me why I was wrong. Finally, about 5 mins after I reported my issue I got an unsolicited sales call, presumably from a different department - unbelievably they tried to sell me a new boiler. He started off by saying ‚ÄúI know you‚Äôve had trouble with your boiler and we couldn‚Äôt get a someone over‚Äù‚Ä¶ he asked my boiler age etc - I thought he was trying to resolve my issue and get someone over faster‚Ä¶. until he proceeded with his sales pitch - ü§¶üèªLordy Lordy

I strongly advice you to steer clear of this company.  I took out service for my combi boiler with them.  I paid monthly then when the boiler broke down on 14th January 2023 I had to pay a fee of ¬£75 before they would agree to send an engineer.  I am 81 years old and was supposed to get priority treatment because of my age.  The engineer didn‚Äôt turn up for 2days.  This happened right at the beginning of that bitterly cold week we had mid January.  The engineer said the boiler needed a new fan and he would return later with that.  After 30 minutes I got a call from the company trying to sell me a new boiler. I quoted what the engineer had said about a new fan.  An hour later I got another call from them trying to sell me a boiler.  I stated quite categorically I didn‚Äôt want a new boiler because my current boiler only needed a new fan.  Later that day I got another call from said company stating the engineer would not be returning with a fan because the boiler didn‚Äôt warrant that expense (about ¬£100).  They refused to refund my monthly payments or the ¬£75 fee.  I got nothing at all for my money.  I subsequently purchased a new boiler - not from them of course.  I was without heat and water for a full week before the new boiler was installed.  Home Rescue couldn‚Äôt have cared less.  Do not under any circumstances give them your money.

Complaint Reference: TF1087026Full Policy ¬£26.99On the first November 2023 I called 24/7 as we had heavy rainfall and there was water leaking from the bottom of the boiler. An engineer came at 6pm in total darkness.  He was immediately rude stating this was his last job and he just wanted to get to the pub. I offered him tea or coffee and he was rude again stating he didn't drink that crap.  I offered him a torch as it was so dark but he didn't want one as he had his phone. I left him to it.  A few minutes later he came in and said he had cut a piece of pipe off and put it on my kitchen worktop.  He said the pipe was incorrectly installed and someone from the office would call me to sort out where we go from there.A couple of weeks later I saw that the drain the boiler pipe went into was overflowing.  I called the company and an engineer came and unblocked the drain. He stated that the pipe was blocked and that is why the water was coming out of the bottom of my boiler and if it hadn't of been dark the boiler engineer would have seen that.  I repeatedly called the company to find out what was being done about my pipework and was told three times that the job had been closed.  I was passed from one department to another and eventually in January 2024 I was told that nobody would be calling out as it was an "incorrect installation".I explained it was installed and maintained under the Worcester 7 year warranty and then has had the last two yearly maintenance certificates by a well known homecare company. So apparently there are 9 gas certified heating engineers that are not doing their jobs properly according to 24/7.  I asked to speak with a manager as I now have an independant quote for ¬£140 bill to pay to repair the cut pipework, I spoke with four different people who appeared to just be reading from a script and not answering my direct questions  and they refused to pass me on to a manager.  I asked to terminate my contract and was told it was yet another department I needed to speak with.   Eventually I was told it would cost me ¬£186 the chap then asked me to wait a moment and then came back saying I could terminate it for ¬£135.  I said the ¬£140 repair that I now had to pay because of their error  should be offset against the ¬£135 to get me out of the contract.  He stated that this was not possible.  I asked once again to speak with a senior person.  I then received a telephone call offering me ¬£30 compensation which obviously said I did not want as I no longer had any faith in the company.  I then received another telephone call the day after offering me ¬£50 compensation, to which I declined.  I was then offered the ¬£50 compensation as part of a reduction of the ¬£186 contract exit fee.  I also received a letter offering the compensation with a detailed letter of my problem stating the dates November 2024 (REALLY).  The incompetencies within this company are outstanding.  Needless to say I have contacted the Worcester boiler company and am prepared to take this further.

As a customer of 247 homerescue Gas Company, I've unfortunately encountered numerous issues that have left me deeply dissatisfied with their services. It's important to note that their offices and call center are located in Pakistan, which often leads to significant communication barriers and frustrating experiences.First and foremost, the technical support provided by 247 Gas Company is severely lacking. The representatives seem to have minimal understanding of technical issues, leading to prolonged wait times on the phone and an infuriating game of passing customers from one department to another. It's incredibly frustrating to deal with individuals who cannot provide meaningful assistance or resolve issues in a timely manner.Furthermore, the gas engineers employed by 247 Gas Company appear to be inexperienced and, in some cases, dishonest. Instead of providing genuine solutions, they often attempt to find faults that can be used as leverage to pressure landlords into expensive repairs. This unethical behavior not only damages trust but also creates unnecessary financial burdens for customers.The complaints department is equally disappointing, displaying a complete lack of understanding regarding the concept of "the customer is always right." Instead of addressing valid concerns, they seem more inclined to dismiss them, leaving tenants in the cold without proper resolution or compensation.Additionally, despite being marketed as a budget-friendly option, 247 Gas Company's premiums have increased substantially without any justifiable reason. In fact, their prices have surpassed even those of larger, more reputable companies like British Gas. This price hike, coupled with their abysmal service quality, makes them a poor choice for anyone seeking reliable gas services.In conclusion, I strongly advise avoiding 247 Gas Company at all costs. While they may offer cheaper rates initially, the subpar customer service, lack of technical expertise, and questionable business practices make them a truly regrettable choice. Save yourself the headache and invest in a more reputable gas provider that values its customers and delivers on its promises.

Booked an annual boiler service only for the central heating system not to work after the engineer had left!  He came back later the same day and said we should have a power flush which would cost ¬£599.  There was absolutely nothing wrong with the boiler (or radiators) prior to him undertaking a service so I find it very hard to understand why a power flush is needed  (and he could not guarantee it would solve the problem).  Surely it was something he did to the boiler that made it suddenly not work.  He was constantly on the phone asking more senior engineers what he should do.  Requested second opinion and engineer booked to attend tomorrow.  Got a call weeks before the service pushing for us to have this power flush and then got two further calls on the day of the service recommending this power flush. I wish I had never booked the annual service as there was nothing wrong with the central heating system! Hopefully the new engineer will be able to sort this out.Update: New engineer found that some valves under the sink area had not been turned back on - so problem solved thanks goodness and power flush not required.The response from the admin team was very good when he came to rebooking an engineer so from a communication and customer service point of view, 24/7 has been excellent.  Just wish they would keep pushing to sell you a power flush even though it is not necessary.

I logged my broken boiler online on Sunday 11th February, I then followed up with a phone call to 24/7 Home rescue on Monday 12th February to find out when I could be booked in.  Engineer visit was booked for Tuesday 13th February. On the morning of 13th February, I received a call 30 minutes prior to the engineer arriving. He arrived on time, was respectful of my white carpets by putting on shoe covers and then did a thorough job of finding the fault with the boiler, and fixing it all in one visit as he had the parts in his van.  I was only without heating and hot water for two days so I am really impressed with how quickly I was booked in and how knowledgeable and efficient the engineer was in fixing my boiler. Would recommend 24/7 Home Rescue, this is my second year signed up with them and the first time I have had to call them out so I am happy with the service and that everything went smoothly.

After a number of companies refusing to service our Back Boiler, this was no issue at all for 247 Homerescue.  Liam arrived and efficiently checked and serviced our Baxi.  All done within the hour, polite and friendly.

10 days so far and no heating at a cost of ¬£400 - not impressed!! And registered with 247 as a vulnerable person (age).I experienced a problem which caused the sockets fuse on the fusebox to trip, and not reset. I called 247 for help on morning of Friday 9 February and described the symptoms. 247 offered to send out an electrician to have a look at the problem for ¬£95 call out fee. Before the engineer arrived on the Saturday I had worked out by elimination that the problem was in a circuit related to the heating system and so had turned off the related isolating switch, and the rest of the electrics worked again.When the electrician appeared, he said he could not find any faults and that I would need a heating engineer, and left. 10 minutes after he left, I could smell electrical burning around the area where the plumbing electrics were. So I isolated the heating circuit again and called 247 (on the Saturday after I semelled the burning) with more details of the problem, and that a heating engineer was needed, as well as an electrician who would review the problem properly...247 said they needed to collect a ¬£95 call out fee before they would send a plumber, during the next week sometime. I paid again, and explained that I was still without heating... so a plumber and an electrician were booked to attend my property on the following Tuesday.The electrician arrived on Tuesday and identified the problem as a faulty Honeywell 2 port valve for the heating. This valve had been replaced by 247 less than 6 months ago. The heating engineer arrived within an hour later and agreed that the 2 port valve was faulty, and that he would need to report this back to 247 for them to decide what to do.I called 247 on Wednesday and Thursday (yesterday) to ask what was happening with getting the problem resolved and get my heating back on...and was told that they were waiting for engineers reports, and waiting for quotes for repairs.Got a call from 247 today saying that I would need to pay ¬£200+ to get the system drained down to complete the repairs - and I have had to pay upfront before they try to source and engineer .... so 8 days without heat later, I am waiting on an appointment to get repairs completed ... so sometime next week....Spectactularly unimpressed... will not be renewing with 247!From 247..."...24-Hour AvailabilityOur claims helpline is always open. If you need us, just call us anytime.  "".... Unlimited Call OutsUnlike some providers, We let you make new claims on our policies as many times as you need because we are always happy to help you."

I don't normally leave reviews, but I feel compelled to share my recent appalling experience with 24/7 home rescue. After a routine boiler service, they flagged my boiler as "at risk," insisting that I needed an immediate replacement of the heat exchanger due to a broken part. This claim was particularly suspicious, considering they had been servicing my boiler for the past three years without any prior issues.They quoted a staggering ¬£900 for the replacement, despite admitting that the fault would have occurred during their own service. Outraged, I contested their assessment, demanding further investigation. Eventually, after many telephone calls, they begrudgingly sent out the boiler manufacturer for a second opinion, only to discover that the supposedly defective part was perfectly fine.This ordeal exposed not only their incompetence but also their blatant disregard for customer satisfaction. I shudder to think about the vulnerable individuals, like the elderly or those unable to advocate for themselves. They would have needlessly forked out a substantial sum for a repair that wasn't even necessary.The lack of accountability and empathy exhibited by 24/7 boiler service is utterly unacceptable. I implore anyone considering their services to proceed with extreme caution. Trusting them with your boiler maintenance could lead to unnecessary expenses and undue stress. Avoid them at all costs, and spare yourself the headache of dealing with their shocking customer service.Complaint Reference Number: HR1088800

I am seeking guidance as I am experiencing high levels of stress and frustration. I‚Äôm not the person who complains but this is getting serious now.In August I have taken landlord home rescue insurance. I have  adviced that as A&e nurse, I may not always be available to promptly respond to phone calls for claims and approvals for my tenant. After the reassurance that  my tenant has been authorised, I have opted for the premium insurance coverage to ensure peace of mind and a smooth process.On January 29th , I had a boiler service. The gas engeneer informed me that he would be turning off the boiler and marking it as risky due to a flu that was not completely sealed on both sides , (there is a gap between the wall and the flue). He explained that this could potentially lead to a CO2 leak back into the property, causing issues. I asked the technician on site if he could repair the necessary work ( that he can issue me an invoice and I will pay for problem to be fixed) and he mentioned that he was not authorized to do so. He advised me to contact the call center, and they would send another engineer to address the issue.On January 30th, I contacted the 24/7 call center and was informed that even this is emergency, my emergency coverage does not cover this work and that a third-party engineer would need to be found, which could take up to two days. After calling again after 2 days I was being told they were still searching for an engineer, I became concerned about enduring three days without hot water and electricity in the cold weather. Consequently, I decided to seek out a private engineer for assistance hoping to fix problem quicker. The call center had no objection and advised me that once the work is completed, I should contact them again so that a qualified engineer can return to the property to service the boiler.Regrettably, I had to travel overseas and my phone's roaming  was not functioning. My tenant have been attempting to communicate with 24/7 , but he was saying that I must speak to them in order to obtain authorization. Consequently, I have sent four emails urgently requesting an emergency visit, as the property still lacks hot water and heating.On February 15th, upon my arrival, I placed a phone call which was subsequently transferred to three different departments. I was given assurance that within 24 hours, an engineer would contact me regarding the appointment details. No one contacted me.On February 16th, 34 hours later, I called again and obtained the job ID. Once more, I was assured that someone would reach out to me within 24 hours. Unfortunately, I wasn‚Äôt contacted.On February 17th I contacted the 24/7  and I was informed me  he needs to place it as a new request since there was no record of a previous one.!Additionally, after one week of my written request for portable heaters as outline in my premium policy, he advised me to purchase the heater myself and submit the receipt.Furthermore, I had made a request to be contacted regarding a complaint by either complaint  team or the supervisor.On Monday, February 19th 12:56, I missed a phone call. I called back after just two minutes, and followed the given voicemail instructions. This led me back to the call center and I was given a new date for engeneer appointment on the 22nd. Once again, I was informed that a new request had to be made for a callback.Consequently, on Wednesday, February 21st, I received a phone call, but due to work commitments, I was unable to answer.Therefore, on Thursday the 22nd, I called again and requested a new callback. On the 23rd, in the evening my tenant confirms that engeneer attended, and that he had to cut off the gas pipe to the boiler.So I call 24/7  trying to find out what happened  but I was informed that it was outside of working hours and there was nothing that could be done. I was advised to wait for the report to be reviewed and for a callback.I am growing increasingly desperate and unsure of what steps to take regarding my tenant's living conditions. It is concerning to see them relying on portable heaters and a kettle for their basic needs.I was unable to get my enquiries sorted via 24/7 mobile app as chat bot is automatic and I wasn‚Äôt offer to chat with live advisor ; neither I was able to log in new claim request.I acknowledge that I missed two phone calls and I appreciate text messages expressing apologies for the negative experience resulting from the phone calls feedback. Regrettably, this does not resolve the issue with the heating and hot water.Is there any regulatory bodies that could provide guidance in this matter?Thanking you in advance for any guidance

Avoid this scam company! Go to other review sites and see the truth about them. I did a service and repair completed last year by this company. I could explain all issues that occurred last time but its pointless. Just be be aware of terms and conditions. This company gets you by delaying its service requirements till a few months into your policy. Then when an engineer is sent to service your boiler, it will not be completed because an issue will highlighted which will abort the service. Now you need to pay for the repair which will not be covered by the policy and worse if you cancel the policy you have to pay a big fee. So according to their terms a call out was made and thus you are liable to their huge cancellation fee. In effect your monthly fees paid so far and cancellation fee or repair cost depending upon your choice will be more than your annual policy cost. So its no loss to them either way. But for you there is no service certificate completed and you need to pay for any repairs before your policy is valid. My boiler is perfectly fine and i would rather cancel my policy than to continue with a company i cannot trust anymore. Will return to my previous company who were only a little more in monthly premiums but so much more professional.

An update on my previous post:I called to say that our heating was making a noise only to be told that they do not come out unless the system is not working.A week or so later the heating did not work and boiler was showing a fault code, so I called again.  The guy told me to turn off at the mains and this seemed to work but said someone would come out.  The system working and making the noise was intermittent and when the engineer came out it was working fine.  I told him the fault was intermittent and told him the fault codes that showed on the boiler.  He hardly looked at the boiler and the pump, said that as it‚Äôs working then he couldn‚Äôt do anything. This cost me ¬£75 excess.However after he went it stopped again so I called out an independent engineer.  Straight away he diagnosed the fault (even though system was working again when he arrived).  He took off the pump and cleaned it out and the system is now working properly and no noise.Basically it‚Äôs cost me ¬£75 excess for nothing.I put a note of complaint on your site and you also said on your reply here that you would get back to me.  I still haven‚Äôt heard anything.  Not impressed.Latest 18/3/2024As above I‚Äôm still waiting for the reply from your complaints department and a reply to the note I put on your web site More latest 2/4/2024You stated in your reply that you would refer to your complaints team and get back to me. We have a fault on our Vaillant boiler that says there is a pressure problem (F.75). It will run for an unpredictable amount of time and then raise the fault again.  A reset will start it again. The boiler is pressurised in the correct range (1.7 bar) so I know that can be excluded, which leaves the pressure sensor or a boiler pump fault. Because the problem is not ‚Äúpersistent‚Äù, in other words, not technically fully broken down, it is not covered by the policy. I was told that if an engineer was to be sent and the boiler was working on arrival, the engineer would leave and my ¬£75 excess would be forfeited. Understandably, I am not happy and wish I had stayed with Corgi, but they wanted 3x the monthly cost, albeit with no excess. I guess if it was to fail completely I would be covered, but I don‚Äôt know if that is going to happen, leaving me with having to reset the boiler at random intervals!!! Looks like I will be finding an engineer I can trust and deciding whether I want to cancel the policy.Update 11th March 2024I tried to trigger the fault while watching the boiler, but only succeeded in getting it into the pressure danger zone of 3.2 bar (the max recommended is 3), at which point I turned it off. Pressure release valve and/or expansion chamber problem? No sign of water being ejected to lower the pressure, which is worrying.After this review went live I had a phone call from the Complaints Resolution team. However, after being passed to the Claims Team yet again I still wasn‚Äôt sure if an engineer would come to investigate and fix what is an obvious problem.Now I have escalated the issue.It seems that I have to pay the excess to get an engineer out to investigate and pass on the details of the problem, if one is discovered, which will then be evaluated by the technical team to see if anything will be done under the contract or I pay to get it fixed.Update 12th MarchA local company engineer arrived and diagnosed the problem immediately. He replaced the pressure sensor and filled the empty expansion chamber. No external authorisation needed. Sorted.After all the hassle and days lost trying to get it fixed, I have lost all confidence in 24/7 being able to handle a problem effectively. I will continue to use the local company. So no more answering the same question multiple times on the same call and being told that I said something I hadn‚Äôt, and no more explaining why the questions I was being asked made no sense, eg ‚Äúhow many times in a day does the boiler exceed the maximum pressure?‚Äù. As I don‚Äôt watch the pressure gauge 24/7 how am I supposed to answer that question? As the Call Centre is in India is it that they don‚Äôt need or use central heating and really have no idea what they are supposedly supporting? No obvious local technical support backup either.I cancelled the contract.

Two things. Firstly, our Carbon Monoxide alarm sounded so we called the emergency (not 247) number. They came in 20 mins and confirmed no leak of Co2 but said they were required to cap the meter so the boiler could be checked for leaks.  Fine.  So we called 247 to come and check the boiler and uncap the meter.  They wanted ¬£95 to come, despite our all singing, all dancing contract with them.  Their reason.....in case there was a problem with the gas hob which is not covered by them.  The kind man on the phone even read the small print buried in sub section, sub section, sub section etc. Just an opportunity for them to grab more money so I called a local heating engineer who came for ¬£60.  He discovered issue number two.  On opening the boiler he found it stuffed with paper towels soaking up a tiny water leak.  The very same boiler that had been serviced by 247 in October.  So either their engineer saw and ignored the water leak and stuffed paper towels in or he didn't actually check the boiler. Either way, unacceptable.  There was no gas leak and the water leak is being fixed. Seems like the Co2 monitor was at fault. Clearly you get what you pay for in life. I will be going back to British Gas as soon as possible.Advice:  Have two Co2 monitors so you can verify if one is faulty/at the end of its expected life. Reference # WS533083

Sadly, my experience with this company doesn‚Äôt deserve a rating. I have been trying to help an elderly relative deal with this company, without much success unfortunately. The reason for them approaching me to assist them, is that I used to be an Area Manager for a High Street bank, and fortunately my close friend is the former Director for General Insurance at the FCA, so we have a good understanding of both General Insurance regulation and Contract Law, which is relevant to this grievance. To give the reader some background to this case, my relative had a boiler on a rented property that was insured through 247 Home Rescue, the boiler being approximately 19 years old. I believe they had been insured with 24/7 Home Rescue for several years, and had called them out previously to the boiler, so the company were well aware of its age. However, on this occasion (despite the policy document being the same as previous years, and their schedule stating zero excess) they refused to go out to the boiler unless my relative paid ¬£75 up front. Being desperate to have the boiler repaired so the Tennant wasn‚Äôt without heat and hot water, she begrudgingly paid the ¬£75, and their engineer appeared. However, he was unable to repair the boiler, pushed for her to have a new boiler, and reported back that the boiler was blocked and required a system flush before a repair could be made etc‚Ä¶ It was at this point I was asked to intervene. My relative rang 24/7 Home rescue and authorised them to deal with me going forward. On the 3rd October 2024 after a great deal of discussion a, manager agreed that my relative had been misled, as her policy document incorrectly stated zero excess on the policy schedule (There fault, not the customers). Despite my explaining that this invalidated the policy, and as no works had been completed, they should cancel the policy and fully refund the customer, as the policy was set up incorrectly (their words not mine), therefore under a regulated policy rules invalidating the policy as the customer was misled. However, all they offered was a ¬£75.00 refund, or ¬£75.00 to be deducted from the repair should she wish to proceed down that route. They advised that they would put these two offers in writing to her by email, and she would need to advise them what she wished to proceed with. Sadly, she never received an email with these offers on (Spam box also checked!!). Despite not having received any email, she contacted them again to advise them that she would like to accept the ¬£75 reimbursement as a minimum. Unfortunately, they claimed they had no record of their conversation with myself, and refused to reimburse her anything. Knowing how much time I had spent trying to resolve this for her, she was too embarrassed to tell my that she hadn‚Äôt received the ¬£75.00 reimbursement. It wasn‚Äôt until I met with her again yesterday, that I asked her if she had been refunded the ¬£75.00 from this company, that she advised me that they denied all knowledge of my call, and was never refunded - Even worse, she was still paying the monthly premium for a product she was mid-sold! To add insult to injury, it would appear she had to get her own heating engineer out to repair the boiler.Upon hearing this, I rang the company yesterday. At first the representative at their call centre denied that they had any of my details in connection with this policy. It wasn‚Äôt until I mentioned a GDPR breach that I was transferred to a different person, who miraculously found the authority on file. They initially didn‚Äôt find the notes relating to my call from the 3rd October, but after approximately 40 Minutes they did, and kept apologising, as it became clear to them that a manager had previously admitted the policy schedule was wrong, and that manager had agreed to at least reimburse the ¬£75.00 that she was wrongly charged. He then offered to reduce the next two premiums by a further ¬£10.00 per month which I accepted on her behalf (but he now corrected the policy to include a ¬£75.00 excess, which I presume is how this company tries to cover its tracks?) - Won‚Äôt work for a pre-existing contract I‚Äôm afraid!!This representative (while continuously apologising), said he needed to put me through to yet another department who will process the ¬£75.00 refund. Sadly, this is where the call went further south. The representative didn‚Äôt want to simply refund the amount, but wanted proof that she‚Äôd repaired the old boiler (Not sure what this has to do with wrongly charging a customer a fee?). After 1 hour, I was cut off ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è  This case is now going to the ombudsman if they don‚Äôt fully refund her premiums paid to date, and her ¬£75.00 they agreed. This will now cost them a further ¬£750.00 in a case fee with the FOS, which is what happens when your staff don‚Äôt understand the law!

Utterly appalling - avoid at all costs!  CO2 alarm went off so we called our local Gas Network.  Engineer shut off gas and advised we get a boiler check done. I was then told as it was 'an overseas call centre' they had no authority to do anything. I received a call (again on a very bad line from overseas) after 9am to be advised that it was not covered by my policy and it would be ¬£95 plus labour!  I have read the T&CS and it clearly states 'Boiler Emergency'.  The SGN engingeer has advised we get the boiler checked in case it has a fault but a boiler policy doesn't cover that? OLDER BOILER? BE VERY WARY OF THIS COMPANY! I have been paying premiums for 5 years to 247 Home Rescue. No claims.  In recent years I got an email to say as my boiler was now over 10 years old, the excess was going up to ¬£75 and premiums were going up 40%.  As I am 65 years old with no family, I thought it was still worth it to be covered in case of emergency.   First claim ever, happened last month.  I had to pay the ¬£75 excess up front, then they sent an engineer out.  He advised it was the pump and would let the office know.  The cost to supply and fit a new pump was ¬£405. I was glad I had insurance.  247 Home Rescue called me later that day and advised my boiler was beyond economic repair and they wouldn't be fixing it.  I asked how they worked this out as it isnt explained in their policy wording.  They said 15 years ago ( the age of my boiler), my boiler would have cost ¬£766 (I have no way to verify this, but possibly?) they don't count installation cost.  With 10% depreciation each year they said it is now worth ¬£156. The repair cost is more than the boiler is worth so they won't pay, or even contribute to the repair.  They won't even send the engineer back to repair it if I pay the ¬£405 in full. Beyond Economic Repair Limit ¬£250? No they won't pay that either.  Value of my boiler ¬£156? No not a chance, theyre not paying anything.They initially refused to pay back the excess charge and simply cancelled my policy! I'm listed as vulnerable on their data base. Goodness knows how they treat people who aren't vulnerable! So 5 years of premiums, ¬£75 excess fee, and they simply said we're not paying anything and your policy is now cancelled.  Oh, but we can sell you a new shiny boiler for ¬£7000 from our sister company.  Conflict of interest, or what?I worked out that even 5 years ago, by their reckoning my boiler was only worth ¬£268.  So inflated premiums and an increased excess charge, really meant they were never going to cover pretty much anything that would require to be supplied and fitted. After 5 escalations (I may be vulnerable, but not stupid), and pointing out wording on their key facts sheet, I eventually got my excess back plus ¬£30 for a small fan heater.  Useless at my property, and I will now have pay for another engineer to come out and do the same tests. This feels very much like a boiler insurance scam to me. So it's off to the Financial Ombudsman to see what they make of these very shady practices.

However I was told I has to now submit a claim for repair as over 7 days has expired. I reluctantly did this and paid the ¬£95 excess.When the second engineer attended he stated we required a new expansion vessel and pressure relief valve. He said he would order the parts and we would be contacted by head office.I later received a call where they stated they would NOT undertake the repair because the cost was ¬£425 and uneconomical due to the age of the boiler, and the only option was to buy a new boiler. I asked them to advise the parts and labour costs, and it was clear they had been over-inflated the repair cost. Absolutely appalling experience with 247 Home Care. Currently, I have a complaint being handled by the Ombudsman service due to their incompetence.A couple of years ago, I had an engineer service my boiler. Despite mentioning that the boiler pressure dropped every few days, the engineer didn't bother checking any of the radiators and simply dismissed it. As expected, the issue persisted and worsened over time, eventually dropping daily. After paying a ¬£95 excess fee, another engineer replaced the expansion valve, claiming it was the problem. Yet, the very next day, the issue recurred. Shockingly, no radiators were inspected for leaks during either visit.Upon contacting them again, I was informed that they couldn't check anything else as per their terms and conditions, leaving me stranded. Days later, my living room radiator pipe burst, causing a major water leak that flooded one side of the room. This resulted in additional expenses of ¬£160 to an independent plumber to secure and replace the damaged valve, not to mention the water damage to my laminating flooring, which is now uneven.Following my complaint to 247, they callously requested all invoices and pictures of damage, only to then wash their hands of any responsibility, claiming it wasn't their fault.To add insult to injury, amidst this chaos, they went ahead and renewed my policy despite my cancelling my auto renewal, then blamed it on me saying their system showed I renewed it. In summary, opting for 247 Home Care is nothing short of a waste of money. Spare yourself the headache, hassle, and stress by choosing a more reliable company. A few extra pounds spent elsewhere could save you from endless frustration.

Before going into the specifics, I want to say that Richard (the senior engineer who managed to fix the issue with my boiler) was brilliant. Very good, thorough, and managed to sort everything in no time, and if I could rate him personally, I would rate him 5/5Having said that, I am rating 24/7 Home Rescue a 1/5 because I cannot choose 0 stars. The whole management process of my claim was appalling. I opened a claim for leaky (1 yo) boiler with loss of pressure on 8th March. The whole situation was resolved (thanks to Richard, again) on 25th April! 7 weeks in total!In those 7 weeks I had:* 4 different engineers attending my property * Each one had a different diagnosis requiring new spare parts to replace* The lowest point was when I had to live without hot water and heating for a whole week (and partly without electricity/internet for 2 days) because one of the engineers who attempted to fix the boiler ended up completely messing things up AND rip some wires off the walls, hence the no electricity* After being very vocal on the phone, Richard was sent to my property on a Saturday and immediately identified the issue. He also fixed the broken electrics straight away and made sure he ordered the (actual!) spare parts needed to fix my boiler once and for all and came as soon as the parts were available. Not a single time was I taken seriously (would anyone live without hot water and heating, especially when it is effectively cold outside?). In short, I would definitely avoid 24/7 Home Rescue as a company but would 100% recommend Richard as a senior engineer. EDIT: Now that the review is live on TrustPilot, I can also say that I was lied to on the phone earlier. I was told that the review (i.e. the rating) would be exclusively about the engineer who fixed my issue, not 24/7 Home Rescue. I argued on the phone that it didn't seem like it would be the case, if the review were to be published. I was assured multiple times that the review would only be about Richard, who was brilliant (as said above). I am quite glad I didn't trust the person on the phone and maintain my 1 (well, 0) star rating for 24/7 Home Rescue. Now on top of a poor customer experience I can add lies to the long list of unprofessional behaviour. EDIT2: As per the response below, it seems that this has been passed onto the complaints team. Very "funny" as when I was asked about raising a complaint, I was told I would be called back. I, of course, never was.

Please be very careful when this company call you and quote for an appliance insurance policy. They do not give all the facts. If you buy a plan the first 30 days you are unable to claim, this I would expect to be normal practice, if your appliances have a breakdown after that 30 day waiting period and the engineer orders your parts and then the parts are on back order with no idea when they will come in , this company will not do anything until you have paid your plan for over 6 months ( never told this when brought) Why 6 months, nearly every other warranty company only have and I believe should have a 30 day waiting period for anything wrong with that appliance, up to a certain limit if a replacement is needed. Not value for money at all, I have realised better plans out there for the same cost .

During 2023 an engineer attended at my property to service the boiler.  This engineer broke a clip holding the inside boiler cover to the boiler itself.  The engineer confirmed to me that he had broken the clip at the time (0.27p each).  24/7 then tried to charge me for this breakage at ¬£109.00 for the engineer to attend back at the property to fix it.  When I queried this 24/7 contacted the engineer who initially admitted to me that he had broken the clip and he also admitted to 24/7 that he had broken the clip.  The clip was replaced free of charge and in this engineer's report it was confirmed that both clips were intact - 24/7 confirmed this to me during my complaint.  Then in 2024 a different engineer attended at the property, admitted he too had broken a clip, the black plastic remnants were on the floor and he told me he had ordered a new clip.  After he left my property, the control panel of the boiler dropped down as this engineer had not screwed it in properly (he told me he could not find his blue screwdriver).  I heard nothing from 24/7 so phoned up and explained what had happened and made a complaint when I was told again, I would have to pay ¬£109.00 to replace the clip (which costs 0.27p) which held the internal boiler cover in place which 24/7 said had caused the control panel to slip and as the clip was not covered in the policy, as the engineer had confirmed that he had not broken it but confirmed to them that it was missing when he arrived at my property on his report, I would need to pay ¬£109.00.  I confirmed that the engineer had indeed broken the clip as I had swept up the evidence.  The complaint was looked into but as the 24/7 engineer had reported that the clip had been missing, which was untrue, the complaint was not upheld so I asked for a manager call back.  This was received and I explained that if the clip had been missing previously, then the boiler cover would have shown signs of this as the cover would not have been on.  The complaint manager refused to accept this or accept that the engineer's report from 2023 confirmed both clips were on the boiler.  I confirmed that no-one had been in the boiler since the last engineer serviced it during 2023 and if the clip had dropped down from the boiler then it would still be within the boxed-in boiler compartment, and it was not.  The complaint was not upheld again and the complaints manager, who totally refused to give me his manager's name etc, told me I would have to pay for a further engineer visit of ¬£109.00. I explained that if the clip was not on the boiler from 2023 then the engineer who attended the property at that time would not have been able to attach the internal boiler cover at that time.  When the boiler was serviced in 2023 there were no signs on the boiler that a clip was missing and no signs that the clip was missing when the engineer attended during 2024.  WOMEN WHO ARE ON THEIR OWN - DO NOT USE THIS COMPANY - the engineer during 2024 said 'I hope I am going to get a thank you when I have finished' - creepy or what!   DO NOT USE THIS COMPANY AS IT WILL COST YOU IN THE LONG RUN AND IT COSTS YOU TO GET OUT OF THE CONTRACT.  BE VERY WISE AND GIVE THIS COMPANY A TOTAL MISS. TOTALLY UNSCRUPULOUS COMPANY AND UNSAFE FOR WOMEN TO USE. 247 replied to this complaint very weakly, stating the 2024 engineer's report said the 'clip was missing", however, the engineer's report from 2023 confirmed that '2 clips were present at that time on the internal boiler cover. So which engineer lied?  No one but the engineer ever goes in the boiler built in cupboard.  Martin Lewis' website has a dossier on 247 and the reviews are dire.  As I said previously, DO NOT USE 247, you will end up paying the price.  Martin Lewis' website is full of complaints about 247 with many dissatisfied customers.

I am deeply disappointed with the service provided by 247. Yesterday evening (29/5), I discovered that my boiler was not functioning, leaving my entire home without hot water. I immediately called the 24/7 helpline at 10 PM, and the customer service representative assured me that they would notify me as soon as an engineer was assigned to address the issue today (30/5).However, by 11:30 AM today, I had still not received any update. I called the helpline again, and the customer service representative kindly followed up on the status of the repair. Regrettably, I was informed that the earliest available timeslot to fix my boiler was on Monday (3/6) - a full 5 days after the initial breakdown.I am shocked and dismayed by this unacceptable delay. I should not have to wait nearly a week to have my boiler repaired, especially given that my whole family left without hot water for the entire duration. This is a wholly unsatisfactory level of service, and I had expected a much more prompt and efficient response from 247.I sincerely hope that the company will review its procedures and resource allocation to ensure that customers experiencing urgent issues can have their problems resolved in a timely manner. This experience has left me deeply dissatisfied, and I would strongly caution others against relying on this company's services based on my disappointing encounter.

Please be wary of the positives reviews. This is LONG! Unfortunately I fall under the ‚Äúshould be no star‚Äù reviews. I called today - 14.06.24 at 11:03. This was after trying to use the App which is rubbish, but now rather telling of this company as they are the same.  I tried to use the chat - luckily I got the number I needed from them of whom to contact. So‚Ä¶ I put my heating on last night and on switching it off -E1 code came up. I topped up the pressure. Now the boiler is 11 years old but is still functioning. Today when I woke up at 6 am, I noticed the boiler pressure had dropped again to E1 and has since done x3 times in the space of 3 hours (after being topped up each time). My partner noticed the carpet in the hall was soaked and we noticed a leak from the radiator. We have made an attempt to turn off but there is water is dripping out and it is next to an electrical point. We have pulled back the carpet and underlay and the floor was soaked. We dried it off and have a dehumidifier set up.  This is relevant because once I managed to get through to someone at 24/7 I explained all this to them. I accepted, paid and then got told that someone would be out tomorrow on 15.06.24 between 10-18:00 with a 30min call beforehand. So I explained they have until 11:03 on the 15.06.24 then! They couldn‚Äôt care less. I wouldn‚Äôt trust them to empty a bath let alone run one. I advised I would have to call a plumber as this is an emergency. They just kept sticking to to the ‚Äú24 hour policy‚Äù jargon. I told them this pointless conversation was cutting into my time to get a plumber so they should cancel the call out and refund the payment. I was told this refund would be between 5-7 days. I ended the call and I found an emergency plumber which is now going to cost me over ¬£200 for a call out but they will be here before 4pm today. During that call I noticed I had three voicemails from 247 - all very difficult to understand due to the background noice, but I did make out they wanted me to call back and confirm if I wanted the call to be cancelled and refunded. I called back and the person I spoke with said it had been cancelled and the refund would be 7-10 days! 3 people at 24/7 and it wasn‚Äôt sorted.  At this point - I wouldn‚Äôt trust them with being able to tell the difference between a bath and a shower! I pay ¬£14.95 a month for this and now I am out of pocket and I have had zero service provided for.  24/7 rescue????? More like ‚Äúhow do you spell rescue‚Äù! Shocking company. And I better get refunded! I can‚Äôt want to not have to be with this company anymore. I may add that my per month amount went from ¬£6.95 per month to ¬£14.95 the next year and I didn‚Äôt get a service in my first year as they have no availability so the they didn‚Äôt provide the boiler check in the first year. I was hesitant to post this review initially, but eventually posted as you might find some thoughts in here useful. I‚Äôm letting a few properties and have had an emergency cover contract with 247 for around 5 years, covering all let and my own property. During these5 years there have been 3 emergency cases altogether and 247 didn‚Äôt provide any emergency support with either: Saniflo systems aren‚Äôt covered (even in case of emergency), leaks must be visible and accessible (now I know track and trace excluded, but why don‚Äôt you state this in bold when advertising your peace of mind?), toilet blockages aren‚Äôt emergencies as long as there is another toilet in the building (regardless of the number of inhabitants), etc. The small print takes care of minimizing 247‚Äôs headache. Ultimately, now having gone through all of this ‚Äì buying the emergency cover won‚Äôt provide you with so heavily promoted ‚Äúpeace of mind‚Äù whatsoever, instead, you acquire a lottery ticket with limited chances of getting help, ending up with even more hassle. Last case: electrics tripping across the ground floor, no domestic hot water, no shower, no fridge, food went off, plus the risk of fire (which was subsequently confirmed upon examination of one of the sockets). 247 couldn‚Äôt bring an electrician the day of logging the request, advised the tenant to expect an electrician next day 9am-7pm. Despite minors staying in the house. By 2 pm next day still no electrician and no updates. Long story short, given the risk of fire, the tenant arranged an electrician through myBuilder platform who turned up 30 mins after the call and did the job within 2 hours.Conclusion: 247 are just a middleman happily taking your money. No peace of mind, good looking on paper but in reality - very limited support with extremely poor turnaround time. I will not prolong my contracts with 247, or any other emergency company, instead, all the money saved will go into a savings bank account forming an ‚Äúemergency fund‚Äù. If anything - myBuilder guys are always there and don‚Äôt hide behind the small print. This is the real peace of mind.PS: just read a nearly identical Trustpilot post, where a customer complained of 247's electrician not considering their electrics tripping as emergency. In their polite response 247 reassured this wouldn't happen again, what an irony 247. Very sad...

I spent weeks looking for boiler home care provider that would be conducive to my Mother & myself, as we both have disabilities. I was with SES but, their services were taken over by Home Serve. I had a few issues with Home Serve customer services which I felt couldn‚Äôt be resolved & mainly, because the renewal contract price, which was extremely unaffordable for my Mother. I did take out a contract with a company called Your Repair but, I cancelled within a few days. They were not able to provide a service that would accommodate the disability needs for my Mother & myself. I then came across 24/7 Home Rescue & I had seen some excellent recommendations from Moneycheck & Heatingforce.I had also read about 24/7 Home Rescue & various reviews on Trust Pilot. I felt quite confident that I had found the right boiler home care provider. Whilst I was applying online to signup to 24/7 Home Rescue, I got a phone call from one of their customer service representatives, whose name is Ajmal. He had seen my online application & that I had used a promotional discount code. He said he could offer me a better offer.Ajmal was very polite & friendly & listened attentively to the problems that I had experienced with other providers. He was very empathetic towards the disability needs of my Mother & myself but, more concerned about by my Mother‚Äôs chronic multiple health issues. She is currently 87 years old & I am also her carer.Ajmal was so courteous & professional at his job & explained everything to me very clearly. He was so kind & patient & I felt that he understood my circumstances & what I was looking for. He provided me with an excellent monthly payment, saving me over ¬£30 compared to my previous providers. After I had setup a new boiler contract with 24/7 Home Rescue, I received another phonecall from call from Ajmal, confirming that he had received all the necessary documents that he needed & confirming that a hard copy of my boiler care contract, would be sent by post, which I have received.I like to thank other customer care representatives who had also called me a few days ago, just to make sure that my Mother & I were happy with everything & I said that we were extremely happy. I can truly recommend 24/7 Home Rescue as a boiler care service provider & for the outstanding customer care that they had provided me.   Thank you

Extremely disappointing Experience with 24/7 Boiler CareI recently had an unfortunate encounter with 24/7 Boiler Care, and I feel compelled to share my experience. Despite paying for their 24/7 call-out service for this year as a cheaper alternative to British Gas, I encountered significant issues when I needed urgent assistance, I guess you get what you pay for, lesson learnt. After an engineer did his annual service, he advised me the PCB had blown, although it was serviceable before his visit. With no heating or hot water, I tried reaching out to them through various channels, but to no avail. The lack of responsiveness and absence of an apology left me frustrated and disappointed.When my boiler was serviced, it was found to be faulty. I expected the repairs to be covered under my policy, but I was informed that certain parts were not included, and it was not economic to repair, which meant a new boiler. This misalignment between what was promised and the actual coverage was disheartening.I strongly advise potential customers to carefully consider their options before choosing 24/7 Boiler Care. While some positive reviews exist, my personal experience has left me questioning the value of their service.There communication is non existent and I feel completely ripped off. They have offered to install a new boiler for a price. I THINK NOT!

Poor Service and Lack of Accountability.I recently had my boiler serviced, and the technician made some changes to the settings. Since the service, the radiators now automatically turning on whenever I switch on the hot water. This issue went unnoticed for eight days, during which time it resulted in unnecessary heating and increased energy bills.When I contacted customer service to address this problem, I was met with confusion and a lack of understanding. They repeatedly questioned how servicing the boiler could affect the radiators, despite my clear explanation of the changes that occurred immediately after the service. Not only did they fail to provide a solution, but they also refused to acknowledge that the issue was caused by the recent servicing.Overall, I'm extremely disappointed with the service and the customer support provided. The lack of accountability and willingness to resolve the issue is unacceptable. I would not recommend this company to anyone looking for reliable and professional service.

I hope someone is fortunate enough to read this review. I‚Äôve been a long-time customer of British Gas and HomeServe, and there's simply no comparison between them and this company. Trustpilot reviews may not reflect the true experience. This company asks for 5-star feedback after a pleasant conversation, but that‚Äôs before you actually need to make a claim or request a repair.Compared to industry standards set by companies like British Gas, this company falls short. While I‚Äôve had my frustrations with British Gas, 24/7 Home Rescue is an outright nightmare. My tenant experienced a leak, and while British Gas had no issues with handling repairs directly, 24/7 Home Rescue created endless obstacles. They don't allow tenants to arrange repairs directly, dragging out the process to the point where my tenant was left stranded while I was on holiday.In contrast, British Gas once promptly repaired a leak under the bath without any fuss. But with 24/7 Home Rescue, they insisted we identify the source of the leak ourselves, asking us to open panels and send them videos. How are tenants or students supposed to do that, especially when the landlord lives two hours away? After endless discussions and phone calls, they never even showed up.When I requested a refund for the 10-11 months we had already paid, they flatly refused. Consider yourself lucky if you see this review and avoid this company at all costs. This nightmare happened 10 months ago, and I‚Äôm still appalled by their service.

I‚Äôve had the plan since December, I‚Äôve not needed an emergency call out but recently booked my annual service. The engineer kept me informed of his estimated arrival and was very friendly when he arrived. he serviced the boiler and gave me feedback about how good condition my boiler was in for its age (11 years). He did say that I‚Äôd receive a report of the service that I haven‚Äôt received yet (2 days later) so not sure what‚Äôs happened to that?? One thing I wasn‚Äôt happy with is a call I got the week before my service trying to upsell a central heating inhibitor (at a cost of ¬£40!),  very hard sell on the phone, basically telling me that my system needed it otherwise my boiler could breakdown but I‚Äôve never had to pay for it when British Gas serviced my boiler for the last decade so why do I need to pay for it now? I have a magnetic filter on my boiler which cleans the rubbish out and the engineer said when he finished how clean my system was so don‚Äôt feel pressured into paying extra for it if you also have a filter fitted. My response to the upsell call was if it‚Äôs needed as part of the service it should be included as part of the service so I‚Äôm not paying for it.. Other than the annoying upsell I couldn‚Äôt fault the service I received from the engineer and would highly recommend 247 for boiler cover‚Ä¶

I‚Äôve had the plan with 247 since December 2023, I‚Äôve not had to call them out for an emergency but recently booked an annual service. The engineer called me giving me an update of his arrival which was helpful and when he arrived he was very chatty and friendly. He serviced my boiler well and remarked that for its age it‚Äôs in great condition (11 years old). He did say that I would receive my service report (I thought by email) but I haven‚Äôt received anything (2 days later) so not sure what‚Äôs happened to that??? One thing that annoyed me was the call I received a week before, I assume from some sales team, trying to upsell me some central heating inhibitor (at a cost of ¬£40!). The caller tried to scare me into getting the inhibitor saying that the boiler needed it otherwise it could breakdown but British Gas had serviced my boiler for the last decade and have never charged me for this, nor was it listed on my service paperwork, so I told the caller that if it‚Äôs needed as part of the service it should be included as part of the service so I‚Äôm not paying for it. My boiler has a magnetic filter fitted to it which clears the rubbish out of the system and the engineer remarked that my system was very clean so I took that as confirmation that I didn‚Äôt need to spend the extra money for the added chemicals. Other than the annoying attempted upsell I had a great experience with the service of the boiler and I couldn‚Äôt fault the engineer‚Ä¶

50 years plus as a customer of British Gas I was surprised on Sunday to receive my annual service renewal document which showed an increase of circa 30%. I phoned to see if there had been a mistake, but to no avail, apparently whilst I thought that I had not made use of the repair facility for 3 years, during the last routine service lubrication of a hive switch (less than a minute) constituted a callout. So sadly I cancelled the product.I searched the internet for a new provider at 77 years of age I was fearful that I had made a hasty decision however the price being asked left me no alternative. I need not of worried as I soon found Home Rescue, their site clearly set out a comparison with many other providers. Further documents clearly explained what was and what was not included in the package. So spoke over the telephone with a very friendly agent who was both knowledgeable, professional and above all humanistic. After answering some simple questions I signed up for home heating and kitchen appliance cover and was pleased to be offered a further 10% discount on the quoted price. (The welcome letter and terms and condition document arrived immediately by email as promised) So I end up paying less than currently let alone the 30% increase requested by BG. With the set up service offered by Home Rescue all my fears have been put to rest. So far seems a very professional organization, so as a pensioner (entered on their priority service schedule without any prompt from me) I have peace of mind for another year. Need not of worried should have changed supplier sooner.

On Sunday 25 August 2024, Following the use of our shower, we suffered a total loss of power in the house. An electrician attributed it to our Boiler.On Monday, we asked for help from 24/7, our insurer, paid ¬£75 for a boiler engineer call-out. He was absolutely useless and confirmed there was a problem of ‚Äúreverse polarity‚Äùand added this to his call sheet.He then said that we need another engineer! We paid another ¬£45 for an engineer for a callout, but he opted to call us on FaceTime to view the Boiler. He then said he would call the Insurer to request a Plumber for us on Saturday but we have never received the call? A further call to company today, Saturday, confirmed no action before Monday, and another charge of ¬£45. I am now arranging for a private Valiant technician to call. As far as 24/7 are concerned, a letter regarding a claim or legal action is my next .  I Would not recommend this company because some of their staff work from home/office and there is background noise. We are pensioners aged 82 and have had no hot water or shower facilities since Sunday 25 August, and have to carry a kettle of hot water upstairs, when needed! We are also both DISABLED!Today, Wednesday, we were asked to call you the claims line. The first person I spoke with could offer us a service in October and there would be another charge. We rejected this offer. Later we received another call and this time an engineer will be coming to our home for a service on Wednesday.Very pleased to say that 24/7 pulled out all the STOPS on Tuesday by sending us a professional engineer who quickly identified three problems requiring replacements. The boiler was then written off and we received vouchers for ¬£495 towards a new boiler if  provided by 24/7. The company are also going to refund the ¬£75 and ¬£45 charges.

Unfortunately I have to write a negative review. My boiler was working fine until the engineer came to do the annual service last week. I have been with 247 for a while now and they have always been really good up until this point. The following morning I woke up to all the radiators being on full blast upstairs even though the heating was turned off. I double checked the thermostat and my cosy system and hoped it was just a blip. The following morning the same thing happened. I called the service centre as I have a service plan. The same engineer came out and said I needed a diverter valve. I received a call from 247 to say that I needed to pay ¬£95 excess plus ¬£108 for a system drain down. As you can imagine I was not happy as everything had been fine before the service. I then asked my partner to have a quick look. The electric motor for the diverter valve had been removed and once this was put in place everything was working well again. I complained and said I wanted to cancel my policy as I have absolutely no faith in the company. They carried out a service and left it not working properly. They said if I wanted to cancel the policy I would have to pay ¬£84!  I am not happy about this as their service, which caused the issue, could have cost me over ¬£200 for something that did not need doing.

Until my renewal date I would have gave a higher rating but this is definitely the worse company I have had to deal with when it comes to a renewal. Firstly they tried to hike my monthly payment to ¬£16.47 from ¬£5.49, I know this is common practice but in the renewal email it stated "If you have an increase, this may be due to a claim you made or because your cover may include a boiler which is now older than the age thresholds of 6 or 11 years, when boilers often need more repairs" my problem is my boiler is 2 years old and I have never claimed, the only service i have used was a boiler service which is included.So because of this I ring them to cancel as I can get the same cover for around ¬£6-¬£7. I speak to a man for a few mins and he tells me he can drop the cover to ¬£12.99, I politely refuse and ask to cancel. He then puts me on hold to speak to his supervisor. When he comes back he tells me he can drop it to ¬£10.99, I politely refuse and ask to cancel to which he puts me on hold again then comes back and says he can drop it to ¬£8.99. at this point I'm getting a little annoyed and telling him I'm finding it hard to stay polite because you are not listening to me, I just wanted to cancel the damn thing. He says ok I will proceed with the cancellation and puts me on hold again. He comes back and says my supervisor has said I can drop the cover to ¬£7.99 but the cover won't be as comprehensive. At this point I'm pretty annoyed and I get a bit more annoyed with him. I tell him to cancel it and he says ok I will proceed with the cancellation and puts me on hold again. He comes back and says that he's about to cancel but his supervisor has said he can drop it to ¬£7.99 for the same cover. I told him that if he would have offered me this in the first place I probably would have said yes to save me having to switch covers but after all this Im definitely cancelling. I was pretty annoyed when I said this so he finally cancelled. This process to around 30mins when it should have took 5. My advise would be don't be drawn in by there low price for the first year as they will hike it more than 200% for the second year and make it really hard for you to leave. As you can see by my review they did not need to hike it that high but they do it hoping you will just take it. Just another Extortionate insurance company.

I hve been a customer of this company for over 5 years but had not called them in an emergency. They are called 24/7 Home Rescue but what is not made clear is that it is the call centre and online logging that is 24/7 but they can take up to 48 hours to arrange an appointment. I had an electrical problem very early on a Sunday morning and I had no working electrical sockets in my house. I logged the call on line. Two hours later I called the company and was told they are trying to get an engineer to me. Two hours later I called again as by now my phone was losing charge, I had no means of cooking or boiling a kettle. I am an elderly widow who lives on her own. I was never asked if  I had means of heating, cooking etc. I was told 'it is a Sunday you know' and they would not be able to get an engineer out. I organised my own electrician that day who resolved the fault. I complained to the company about the service and received a very condescending email reply saying that they could have offered me an appointment for the Tuesday but I had already resolved the issue. I would have been without any electrical appliances for 2.5 days at that point. I was offered a refund of one months premium but this offer was withdrawn when I said I wanted to cancel my policy.  I can understand that emergencies have to be prioritised but I was left with no electrical appliances, no landline phone (as linked to the broadband) and a flat battery on my mobile phone. Very disappointed by their lack of any care for their vulnerable clients.
